Field of Study  Global and Transcultural Images and Screen Studies Interaction and Social Processes Persuasion and Politics Technology and Society              MCC-UE 1517 - Photography and the Visual Archive        This course examines the role and history of photography within the historical landscape of media and communication. Special emphasis is placed on the accumulative meaning of visual archives, tracing how images relation and establish cultural territories across a variety of texts and media. The course investigates and contrasts the mimetic visual strategies within western and non-western traditions, looking at historical and contemporary images in a variety of forms. View sample syllabus                     This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. All rights reserved.   NYU Steinhardt - Media, Culture, and Communication - 239 Greene Street, 8th Floor, New York,  NY 10003

Visual History Archive of the USC Shoah Foundation Institute - NYU Libraries                               This is the "Visual History Archive of the USC Shoah Foundation Institute" guide.      Alternate Page for Screenreader Users      Skip to Page Content                                             Visual History Archive of the USC Shoah Foundation Institute         Last update: Jun 13, 2014        URL: http://guides.nyu.edu/content_mobile.php?pid=99074                                                                          What is the Visual History Archive?                                                                                  About the VHA                 In 1994, Steven Spielberg established the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation with the goal of gathering video testimonies from survivors and witnesses of the Holocaust. Between 1994 and 1999 the Foundation recorded over 52,000 testimonies in 56 countries and in 32 languages. These testimonies have been digitized and indexed and are now accessible to educators, students, and researchers all over the world.   Interviews are broad-ranging and include: Jewish survivors, homosexual survivors, Jehovah's Witness survivors, liberators and liberation witnesses, political prisoners, rescuers and aid providers, Sinti and Roma survivors, survivors of Eugenics policies, and war crimes trials participants.    Since 2006, the Visual History Archive of the Shoah Foundation Institute has been a part of the College of Letters, Arts and Sciences at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. Its mission is to “overcome prejudice, intolerance, and bigotry—and the suffering they cause—through the educational use of the Institute’s visual history testimonies.”   For more information go to the Shoah Foundation Institute site           Comments (0)                                         The Archive in Research & Teaching                  Sampling of classes using the VHA  Selective list of publications that draw on the VHA            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Using the Visual History Archive @ NYU                                                                                  Guides for the VHA                 Some excellent guides to aid the in-depth researcher:  VHA User Manual 55 pages of information on using the Archive for in-depth research.  VHA Thesaurus "...lists the indexing terms used to describe the Institute’s video testimonies and arranges them hierarchically under broad headings. These terms have been assigned directly to digital time codes within testimonies where the specific topics are discussed...."            Comments (0)                                         Using the Archive @NYU                 The Visual History Archive is available for research to the NYU community and to users not affiliated with NYU. (See below, for access specifics regarding non-affiliated users).   Before your visit you may already want to search the catalog for the  Visual History Archive . Approximately 1,100 English-language testimonies (out of  nearly 52,000 videotaped interviews) can be viewed in the Visual History Archive Online . Testimonies not available through VHA Online can be viewed onsite through the Bobst Library subscription to the Visual History Archive .   Let us know the testimonies you would like to access by emailing the testimony numbers to vha.library@nyu.edu .   Testimonies are streamed from an NYU cache server, connected to Internet2, and are therefore available on campus only . You may bring your own headphones or borrow a set from us.   System requirements are as follows:   Windows Vista, 7, and 8 with Google Chrome, Internet Explorer 9 or above, or Firefox 22 or above   Mac OSX 10.6 or above with Safari 5.1.1 or above, or Google Chrome (Firefox is not currently compatible on Macs with the new files)     It is recommended that every first-time user of the VHA make an appointment for a research consultation by contacting us at: vha.library@nyu.edu       Before using the Archive a one-time registration is required. See Terms of Use .      Enter the Visual History Archive              Comments (0)                                         Access for the Non-Affiliated User                 User     contact us at  vha.library@nyu.edu to set up a research appointment     VHA Staff     for the initial research appointment provide the Library Privileges desk with the user's name, to be entered into the appointment log   during the research appointment fill out the Special Collection Extended Pass Form (please find the link to the form, below)     User      take the Special Collection Extended Pass Form to the Library Privileges desk to be issued an orange-colored library pass, which grants daily access to the library from 7:00 AM to 1:00 AM.    after pass expires, contact us at  vha.library@nyu.edu for a new  Special Collection Extended Pass Form    take this  Special Collection Extended Pass Form to the Library Privileges desk to be issues another library pass                 Special Collection Extended Pass Form            Comments (0)                                         Copyright FAQ's                 Wondering whether you can reproduce sections of transcripts in your publication? Wondering whether you can make audio recordings of whole or partial testimonies?   Check out the FAQ's on Copyright --             Questions pertaining to Usage Rights and Copyright            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Other Holocaust Resources                                                                                  Resource Guide for Holocaust Studies                  Research Guide            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                 Description  Loading content... please wait                                     More Information  Loading content... please wait       Close window                           ^ Top  |  Home Page  |  Full Site                                           Powered by Springshare and iWebKit.
